Food and Music: The Revolution York Has Been Craving

10/10/2021

Tabitha Kaye considers the new music and food trend in York and why these venues are an exciting addition to the current music scene.

Image by Image Credit Jimmy's York

By Tabitha Kaye

Admittedly, when I was first introduced to York in 2019 my first thoughts consisted of â€˜the Minster Choirâ€™ and â€˜the Crescentâ€™ when music was brought up in conversation. While a few music venues offer the odd bag of crisps to balance a pint, my thoughts were far from food.

Fast track to 2021 and I am overwhelmed by the York music scene. In my desperation to escape the confines of my lockdown room, I had scoured â€˜Indie Yorkâ€™ to plan my optimistic return to Uni. After a taste of in-person gigs and societies during first year, my heart was set on a music-immersive experience.

As you can imagine, FortyFive vinyl cafÃ© was a must. As an added bonus, I stumbled across Yorkâ€™s newest addition, Jimmyâ€™s, during my quest. Both were a stark contrast with what I had been used to and it intrigued me. What was happening to York? The idea of a music and food revolution was tantalising â€“ not just for the tastebuds, but for the imagination too.

For any music lover, the FortyFive Vinyl cafÃ© is a dream. A passion for everything music-related permeates through the expressionism of co-owners and musicians, Dom White and Dan Kentley. The walls of the cafÃ© are adorned with an eclectic mix of Swissted typography posters, ranging from Bowie at Dunstable Civic Centre to Public Enemy at Washington DC, which add an in-keeping modernist twist to an otherwise cosy aesthetic.

Although, what stands out the most is how the customer is invited to share the experience. And, surprising or not, it is FortyFiveâ€™s famed grilled cheese sandwiches and the house blend coffee which act as the perfect conduits for customers to express(o) their own tastes. The â€˜Greatest Hitsâ€™ selection sets the stage with diners being able to identify with witty and playful wordplay, such as â€˜Mexican Fenderâ€™ and â€˜I am the Egg (Plant) Man.â€™ If your favourite artist hasnâ€™t been featured in pun form, why not craft your own musical toastie with the â€˜Create Your Ownâ€™ option?

In-keeping with White and Kentleyâ€™s ethos of exposing new artists and creating a friendly space, no taste is left un-catered for. For those who are more casual listeners or harness different tastes, the basis of FortyFive as a cafÃ© allows for musical inclusivity. Part of the cafÃ©â€™s unique blend of food and music is their vinyl store, with offerings ranging from Â£5 Cliff Richard LPâ€™s to classic AC/DC and new releases. The option to browse and nurse a coffee simultaneously offers a novel and relaxed way to appreciate music.

Anyone who is a purveyor of rock â€˜nâ€™ roll bars and cafÃ©s will feel at home at Jimmyâ€™s. The joint restaurant and bar epitomises the best aspects of the rock scene in both feeling and aesthetic: welcoming staff lead you through a haze of electric red to your table, where customers are greeted by a unique and indulgent â€˜BBQâ€™ menu.

While a specific music link is never stated explicitly beyond the rock â€˜nâ€™ roll theme, the Jimmyâ€™s experience hints frequently at a plethora of influences. On the website, nineties grunge tones are scorched by flashes of red, and a mix of Britpop, rock and indie can be heard playing during the daytime hours. Both serve as the perfect warm up for the night-time act: a deeper intensity of musical tone with a flowing and buzzing bar.

While Jimmyâ€™s in York is still fairly embryonic, the wider franchise -venues in Manchester and Liverpool- reveal a deeper story. Founding brothers and musicians, George and Jimmy Craig, opened the original Manchester branch as a live music venue following their position as regulars on the York music patch at the turn of the millennium.

With this in mind, it is fair to say that Jimmyâ€™s hit the inclusivity mark well. Similar to the successes of FortyFive, the Craig brothers demonstrate how hearty food and a diverse playlist make for a welcome atmosphere.

As a city we are lucky to boast so many live music venues. Although, after Covid it is refreshing to see some imaginative alternatives to the traditional gig environment we are used to. While both businesses predate the virus, their unique music and food offerings have encapsulated this ideology.

One of the saving graces of lockdown was how it probed many to rekindle past hobbies. For many, music was a mainstay and prompted the population to reconsider how they interacted with music, and a desire to attend gigs was tested against the online Zoom vortex.

With this in mind, it is no surprise that FortyFive and Jimmyâ€™s are the forerunners of the music and food revolution which appears to be sweeping York. As FortyFive proclaims proudly on their website, the cafÃ© is â€œowned by musicians and run by musicians.â€ With a different approach, Jimmyâ€™s undeniably fit the bill, welcoming all types of musicians and music lovers for an alternative experience.

In a post-Covid world, both stand testament to how food and music is the revolution York has been craving.
